message_1: Determine the truth value of the proposition "If 2 + 2 = 5, then 6 - 3 = 4."
message_2:
This proposition is an example of a conditional statement, which is in the form "If P, then Q." In this case, P is "2 + 2 = 5" and Q is "6 - 3 = 4." 

A conditional statement is considered true unless a situation arises where P is true and Q is false. In this case, P is false because 2 + 2 = 4, not 5. Since P is false, the conditional statement is true regardless of the truth value of Q. Therefore, the proposition "If 2 + 2 = 5, then 6 - 3 = 4" is true.
